title: D.I.C.E. Blight Abatement Report
text:
D.I.C.E (Data Informed Community Engagement), is the City Of Dallas’s Office Of Integrated Public Safety Solutions (OIPSS) mission operationalized. OIPSS’s mission is to enhance the general welfare and protection of Dallas residents from risks that affect persons, property and the collective well-being of residents. The DICE process guides crime prevention efforts by combining data analysis with community-led risk narratives to learn where and why people tend to commit crimes in certain settings. This plan describes how the use of risk modelling combines with community involvement to guide violence reduction efforts at places of highest risk. The highest risk locations for violent crime in the city¹ make up only 3% of the land area of the City of Dallas but account for 21% of the total violent gun crimes².




Reference 1

Reference 2




Crime prevention efforts come in a wide array of solutions. Blight remediation, transformative change, and clean and green beautification efforts are just a few examples of how to heal a community or neighborhood, from historic and systematic neglect that harbors violent crime. Our community partners work vigilantly to apply the solution in the communities they themselves are already implemented in. This tool is a view of all of the work being done by CPAL’s neighborhood and community partners, as well as OIPPS’s efforts.




City-Wide Impact of D.I.C.E. Initiatives




1,942
Pounds of Trash Removed






15,550
Pounds of Produce Distributed






178Average Individuals Served Monthly






0Properties Transformed






Impact data updated monthly, last update 7/10/24.



Cleaning and Greening




As outlined in the official OIPSS D.I.C.E overview, clean and green abatement is a key environmental intervention in this work. The broken glass theory summarized states that signs of disorder will lead to more disorder. The clean and greens are a mobile, and effective way to combat blight on a community and grassroots level. Each community organization partnered with CPAL for the D.I.C.E. initiative, cleans and remediates their prospective division, and the focus areas within the divisions. These monthly clean and greens allow for the mobilization of residents in the focus areas to also participate in beautifying their communities.






















Produce Drives
Between division site visits and observations coupled with D.I.C.E. event surveying and community feedback one thing became very apparent and stark about each focus area, it was within or around a food desert and food swamp. The surveying we did directly from the community repeatedly mentioned the want for fresh fruits and vegetables and having the ability to afford them. The DICE produce drives allow for real scale across the city to address food issues in the focus areas, as well as safety surrounding the issues of food insecurity as well. Hungry communities harbor unsafe and oftentimes dangerous conditions. Empowering and supporting our community partners who already do this work is essential to the success of this initiative. Without real partnership, scale of this magnitude wouldn’t be possible.


























Locations of D.I.C.E. Work

title: Collaborators
text:
The Office of Integrated Public Safety Solutions (OIPSS) was created in April 2020. Under the R.E.A.L. Change Initiative implemented by the City Manager, the OIPSS works proactively to address systemic factors that contribute to criminal activity by providing non-law enforcement solutions that improve the quality of life in the community and reduce the demand for police service.






Crime Prevention Through Environmental Design or CPTED (pronounced sep-ted) suggests that the design of buildings, landscaping and outdoor environments can either encourage or discourage crime. CPTED attempts to minimize crime and the fear of crime by reducing criminal opportunity and fostering positive social interaction among the users of a space. The proper design and effective use of the built environment, can lead to a reduction in the fear of crime and the incidence of crime, and to improvement in the quality of life. The three elements of CPTED are Territoriality, Surveillance and Access Control. When used together, these elements strengthen total premise security and personal safety.

title: South West Division
text:
Pounds of Trash Collected
675















Bags of Produce Distributed
186
















Average Individuals Served 
124














Properties Transformed
-











Impact data updated monthly, last update 7/10/24.


The focus areas in the South West are Chaucer Pl and Camp Wisdom, and Camp Wisdom and Preferred Place. Both areas are near the Redbird area of Dallas, a historically Black upper middle class and working class area. Chaucer Pl and Camp Wisdom has six apartment complexes near it within a thousand foot radius. The area also has a good mix of residential housing surrounding it. The areas have three schools within a half mile radius of each other, and the focal point of the community, Redbird Mall, has undergone massive upgrades and investment over the past few years. The investments have made the mall area better, but have no effect on the area outside of the mall like Camp Wisdom and Preferred Place directly across the street. Camp Wisdom and Preferred Place is plagued by open air drug sales, motels/hotels that harbor elements that lead to gun violence in the area, prostitution, illegal gaming rooms and a host of more criminal related activities that keep the area extremely unsafe for the families and residents that reside in it. The City Of Dallas also plans on opening up a houseless shelter, the first of its kind, near the problematic hotels/motels on Preferred Place sometime in 2024.

    “The area is changing slowly. I grew up here so I've seen a lot and heard alot. I wish as a kid I had more to get into over here, I didn't realize how  little we had until I got older. The mall being revitalized is cool, I work there so i'm happy about that. But the mall aint gonna help the area get good. Im interested in seeing the next wave of changes to come”
    Community Resident
    




Community Needs Assessment




Public Space Improvements




2800 Camp Wisdom Rd, Before







2800 Camp Wisdom Rd, After









    “It's nothing for the kids, man. It's sad lowkey. It's a gang of apartments full of children and they get in trouble because there isn't anything to do. No park, no rec center, no court, nothing. We need to change that.”
    Community Resident
    
The area lacks parks and public spaces for youth to convene. Without safe and fun spaces to spend their time, local youth are more likely to become involved in illegal activity. D.I.C.E plans to transform a vacant lot to meet this need.





    “Economic development is all the talk, but I  don't see any of it happening on this side of 67. The young people over here carry guns, shoot at each other, kill each other, rob each other. It's insane. This area needs to be cleansed by jesus. I try my  best to guide the young folks around me as best as I can but there are so many misguided. We need help”
    Community Resident
    





Code Enforcement

Retail strip owners are complacent in the operation of illegal gambling rooms and the sale of unauthorized liquor. Local hotels are often the site of illegal sex work and open air drug sales. The risk of gun violence and crime in the area increases due to the presence of these elements.





Distribution of Fresh Food












    “It used to be worse when gangs ran heavy over here. I would like to see more things for families to do come over here. It's good that Red Bird mall is being redone, but that's just the mall. The whole area needs to be redone.”
    Community Resident
    
Residents lack access to fresh, healthy food. The area is a food swamp, saturated with low quality, highly processed options. As the majority of residents rely on public transportation, traveling to obtain fresh food is an unrealistic option. Fresh food must be brought in and distributed locally.



Urban Blight Abatement Initiatives


Cleaning and Greening

title: South Central Division
text:
Pounds of Debris Removed
320















Bags of Produce Distributed
162
















Average Individuals Served 
68














Properties Transformed
-











Impact data updated monthly, last update 7/10/24.


The focus area in the South Central division is Bonnie View Rd and Springview, also known as Fruitdale. This area exists in a barren food desert. It is surrounded by residential houses with three sets of apartments within a quarter mile radius. W.W. Bushman is the elementary school closest to the focus area and is set to open as a brand new state of the art campus in the 2024 Fall semester. A high concentration of families and elderly residents reside in the area. Houseless residents are in the area and present unique issues for the nearby apartments that they frequent, causing nearby apartment complexes to unintentionally harbor elements that create issues around gun violence in the area. The area has been generationally neglected and plagued with a plethora of issues which is why the data lead directly to it.




Community Needs Assessment








3728 Bonnie View Rd, Before







3728 Bonnie View Rd, After








Public Space Improvements

    “I can't wait to get me and my kids out of here. It's cool for a starter apartment or getting on your feet, but this is not a place where I want to raise my kids long term. I plan on moving within the next four to five months”
    Community Resident
    
The area lacks parks and public spaces for youth to convene. Without safe and fun spaces to spend their time, local youth are more likely to become involved in illegal activity. D.I.C.E plans to transform a vacant lot to meet this need.




OIPSS CEPTED Assessments

    “It’s not good at all, man. It's a cult that lives in the woods back there. Young kids shooting guns and shit and driving cars crazy. People doing dope all over the place. Its bad man”
    Community Resident
    





The Dallas Office of Integrated Public Safety Solutions (OIPSS) has been activated in the area to address inadequate property security. Crime Prevention Through Environmental Design (CEPTED) Assessments have been conducted, and camera towers have been installed where needed.
Follow link for more information about CEPTED work.








Local home in need of roof and fencing repairs.







Local property with broken windows and inadequate fencing.








Housing Remediation

    “I lived here for forty years, me and my mama. Nothing has changed much at all. We never had anything over and never expected to get anything over here.”
    Community Resident
    
Local buildings have been neglected. Fences, windows, and roofs are broken and in need of repairs.



Urban Blight Abatement Initiatives


Cleaning and Greening

title: South East Division
text:
Pounds of Trash Collected
660















Bags of Produce Distributed
442
















Average Individuals Served 
290














Properties Transformed
-











Impact data updated monthly, last update 7/10/24.


The focus areas in the South East are RL Thornton and Jim Miller, and Murdock and Loop 12. Both areas are entrenched heavily in food swamps. Both areas are also adjacent to major freeways in Dallas, I-30 and 175. In the RL Thornton and Jim Miller area there are three motels within a half mile radius that are utilized as extended stays. This area has a set of apartments near, with residential housing being within a quarter mile radius. Historically, the area has always been working and middle class. The area has recently succumbed to a lot of business and retail neglect. Places that were occupied three to five years ago aren’t any longer. Those places not being occupied have harbored opportunities for gun related crimes to occur. Murdock and Loop 12 sits at the corner of a problematic convenience store and the parking lot of a grocery store. The area has three sets of apartment complexes within a quarter mile radius that’s surrounded by residential housing. There are three schools serving this community within a half mile radius. Home to primarily working class people, this area has been historically neglected and severely affected by systematic divestment.

    “I’ve never felt safe over here, I'm just surviving. People's cars get broken into over here. There have been more houseless people in the area in the past year or so. The food options are bad, and the only grocery store nearby is WalMart. I heard a story recently about the RaceTrac almost getting robbed a couple weeks back. It's the wild west over here." 
    Community Resident
    




Community Needs Assessment































Fence Repair

    "There's too much foot traffic in and out. Security is there but they dont do much. The park is really an issue."
    Community Resident
    
Fencing is heavily damaged along properties. This includes overgrown plants and large holes. Certain sections are dilapidated and literally falling down. This is a huge safety risk to nearby residents.




Trash Support

    "Quam viverra orci sagittis eu volutpat odio. Nisl condimentum id venenatis a condimentum vitae."
    Community Resident
    
Trash services need support in the area. The build up and overflow of trash poses an extreme health safety risk for the residents.


















































Improved Bus Stops

    "Public transportation is essential here. More covering for the bus stops and more adequate bus stops in general. There are about four or five stops within a five hundred foot radius of one another. None are adequate."
    Community Resident
    



Urban Blight Abatement Initiatives


Cleaning and Greening



    "At the inaugural Clean and Green event, we successfully cleaned multiple parking lots and storefronts that were heavily littered, making a significant difference all the way up to the doors. The positive feedback from store managers, owners, and patrons underscores the impact and importance of our efforts in improving the local environment. In addition to the physical cleanup, our Clean and Green event fostered a strong sense of community within the neighborhood. By working together toward a common goal of beautification and environmental stewardship, we strengthened bonds among residents and businesses, creating a more connected and supportive community spirit."
     Tramonica Brown, founder of Not My Son

title: North Central Division
text:
Pounds of Debris Removed
30















Bags of Produce Distributed
218
















Properties Transformed
-














Average Individuals Served Monthly
113











Impact data updated monthly, last update 7/10/24.


The North Central division has the focus area neighborhood of Esperanza. The Esperanza neighborhood is on the border of two cities, Dallas and Richardson. The neighborhood is a mix of housing and apartment complex residential living. There are five schools within a half mile radius and a very high concentration of families in the area. The area historically has been problematic, Esperanza Rd used to be called Maham Rd (pronounced Mayhem) until a name change came in 2017 as part of the revitalization of the area. Statistically it’s one of the higher crime areas in Dallas, but that’s often overlooked and overshaded due to the area around it being primarily business towers, company campuses and at the corner of two major Dallas freeways. The area recently has had major issues with homelessness and houseless encampments, especially in the Cottonwood Creek/Park area. As a result of the neglect, the area has continued to see spikes in violent crimes and especially violent gun crimes over the past few years.




Community Needs Assessment








Fencing Before D.I.C.E. Intervention











Fencing Before D.I.C.E. Intervention













Fencing after D.I.C.E. Intervention







Fencing after D.I.C.E. Intervention








Fence Repair

    "There's too much foot traffic in and out. Security is there but they dont do much. The park is really an issue."
    Community Resident
    
Fencing was heavily damaged along properties, including overgrown plants and large holes. This was a huge safety risk for nearby residents.




Trash Support

Trash services needed support in the area. Esperanza is primarily residential, housing several families in close proximity. The build up and overflow of trash in and around residences posed an extreme health safety risk for the residents, particularly the children. Monthly clean ups by local partners Not My Son, United Peoples Coalition, and activated community members have been successful. Local properties have increased the size of their dumpsters and frequency of trash pick-ups.










Trash before D.I.C.E Intervention











Trash After D.I.C.E Intervention













Trash Before D.I.C.E Intervention







Trash After D.I.C.E Intervention


























Improved Bus Stops

    "Public transportation is essential here. More covering for the bus stops and more adequate bus stops in general. There are about four or five stops within a five hundred foot radius of one another. None are adequate."
    Community Resident
    



Urban Blight Abatement Initiatives


Cleaning and Greening

title: North Central Division

title: North Central Division
text:
Heading

Fencing Repair

    "There's too much foot traffic in and out. Security is there but they dont do much. The park is really an issue."
    Community Resident
    
Fencing is heavily damaged along properties. This includes overgrown plants and large holes. Certain sections are dilapidated and literally falling down. This is a huge safety risk to nearby residents.

title: North West Division
text:
Pounds of Trash Collected
170















Bags of Produce Distributed
275
















Average Individuals Served 
284














Properties Transformed
-











Impact data updated monthly, last update 7/10/24.

The North West division focus areas are the Wycliff and Hondo St, Crown Hill Memorial Park area and Bolivar Ln and Larga Rd. Crown Hill Memorial Park and Bolivar and Larga Rd areas are very high density apartment areas. The neighborhood has a very large immigrant population from a plethora of countries. Most of the residents live near or around Dallas Love Field Airport, which in turn subjects the community at large to an inordinate amount of noise pollution. The focus areas of Bolivar and Larga, and Crown Hill Memorial Park struggle with homelessness, which has become a major issue for both residents and business owners in the area. The area has six schools in a quarter mile radius and is currently a food swamp. The violent crime in the area often goes under and unreported due to the immigrant population being afraid of not only the community repercussions, but the legal ones as well. The area has historically always been working and lower middle class but constant neglect, and divestment from that community have made conditions exponentially worse over the past five to six years.



Community Needs Assessment































Fence Repair

    "There's too much foot traffic in and out. Security is there but they dont do much. The park is really an issue."
    Community Resident
    
Fencing is heavily damaged along properties. This includes overgrown plants and large holes. Certain sections are dilapidated and literally falling down. This is a huge safety risk to nearby residents.




Trash Support

    "Quam viverra orci sagittis eu volutpat odio. Nisl condimentum id venenatis a condimentum vitae."
    Community Resident
    
Trash services need support in the area. The build up and overflow of trash poses an extreme health safety risk for the residents.


















































Improved Bus Stops

    "Public transportation is essential here. More covering for the bus stops and more adequate bus stops in general. There are about four or five stops within a five hundred foot radius of one another. None are adequate."
    Community Resident
    



Urban Blight Abatement Initiatives


Cleaning and Greening

title: North East Division
text:
Pounds of Debris Removed
87















Bags of Produce Distributed
272
















Average Individuals Served 
154














Properties Transformed
-











Impact data updated monthly, last update 7/10/24.


The North East division focus area is Walnut St and Audelia Lane and extends to Forest Lane and Audelia. The area has been historically, and remains somewhat, economically middle on one side (Walnut St) and poor working class on the other (Forest Lane) . The particular focus area of Walnut and Audelia was formerly a bustling Asian based shopping center catering to the demographic that used to live in the neighborhood. The Walnut Mall, a large component of the shopping center, sits empty today. The area consists primarily of apartment complexes extending from Forest Lane to Walnut St. Gangs used to operate heavily in the area and have died off since about 2018, but gun related crimes from robberies to carjackings still remain an issue for both residents and business owners in the area. The neglect that historically existed in the Forest Lane Audelia area seems to have extended into the Walnut and Audelia area. A common theme amongst the Northern divisions of Dallas.

    “The area has changed immensely over the past few years. It's not as bad as the other end (Forest and Audelia). I've heard about the issues in the apartments regarding car break-ins and robberies, but not much in the houses where I live. It's usually quiet.”
    Community Resident
    




Community Needs Assessment





    “I've been over here for about nine months now and it's terrible to me. I try to keep to myself and just go to work because I really don't feel safe over here. The shopping center across the street has some cool food options but I wouldn't be there past a certain time. Down the street (Forest Ln and Audelia Rd)  is worse. I've seen more police patrols lately but nothing really outside of that. The apartments around here need better security overall" 
    Community Resident
    





Security Improvements

    “ We’ve dealt with our own issues in regards to car break ins. It isn't frequent but it does happen, similar to what other apartments in the area. Our residents are pretty vigilant about reporting things and notifying us and or the police when things happen."" 
    Apartment Manager
    
This focus area is down the street from one of the most violent areas in Dallas, Forest lane and Audelia. Eight apartment complexes are within a quarter mile of the area, and are the site of car break-ins and robberies. Security improvements are necessarily to protect residents, as well as improve their well being.




Nisl condimentum

    "I would love to see more things for the kids in the area. We try to have things up here for them but the demand is so much its hard to keep up with"
    Apartment Manager
    


















































Improved Bus Stops

    "Public transportation is essential here. More covering for the bus stops and more adequate bus stops in general. There are about four or five stops within a five hundred foot radius of one another. None are adequate."
    Community Resident
    



Urban Blight Abatement Initiatives


Cleaning and Greening





    "I've determined my location has needed less and less attention on the trash pick up. The apartments have noticed the work we're doing and are making an effort to keep it clean"
    Community Partner, July 2024

title: DICE Blight Abatement Report
text: Cleaning and Greening Initiative

title: DICE Blight Abatement Report
text:
Produce Drives
Between division site visits and observations coupled with DICE event surveying and community feedback one thing became very apparent and stark about each focus area, it was within or around a food desert and food swamp. The surveying we did directly from the community repeatedly mentioned the want for fresh fruits and vegetables and having the ability to afford them. The DICE produce drives allow for real scale across the city to address food issues in the focus areas, as well as safety surrounding the issues of food insecurity as well. Hungry communities harbor unsafe and oftentimes dangerous conditions. Empowering and supporting our community partners who already do this work is essential to the success of this initiative. Without real partnership, scale of this magnitude wouldn’t be possible.

title: Collaborators
text:
Crime Prevention Through Environmental Design or CPTED (pronounced sep-ted) suggests that the design of buildings, landscaping and outdoor environments can either encourage or discourage crime. CPTED attempts to minimize crime and the fear of crime by reducing criminal opportunity and fostering positive social interaction among the users of a space. The proper design and effective use of the built environment, can lead to a reduction in the fear of crime and the incidence of crime, and to improvement in the quality of life. The three elements of CPTED are Territoriality, Surveillance and Access Control. When used together, these elements strengthen total premise security and personal safety.

title: Collaborators
text:
The Office of Integrated Public Safety Solutions (OIPSS) was created in April 2020. Under the R.E.A.L. Change Initiative implemented by the City Manager, the OIPSS works proactively to address systemic factors that contribute to criminal activity by providing non-law enforcement solutions that improve the quality of life in the community and reduce the demand for police service.






Crime Prevention Through Environmental Design or CPTED (pronounced sep-ted) suggests that the design of buildings, landscaping and outdoor environments can either encourage or discourage crime. CPTED attempts to minimize crime and the fear of crime by reducing criminal opportunity and fostering positive social interaction among the users of a space. The proper design and effective use of the built environment, can lead to a reduction in the fear of crime and the incidence of crime, and to improvement in the quality of life. The three elements of CPTED are Territoriality, Surveillance and Access Control. When used together, these elements strengthen total premise security and personal safety.
